data.stimulus:
READING SECTION

 

QUESTION 1 - READING FOR MAIN IDEAS

Match the headings 1-8 to the paragraphs A-H
data.template:
1. The cost of living in the capital {{response}}
  2. High-speed rail in Europe {{response}}
  3. An alternative rail solution {{response}}
  4. Cost of running an HSR network {{response}}
  5. Opposing views on the HS2 project {{response}} 
  6. Negative economic impact of HS2 {{response}}
  7. The main reasons for funding HSR in Britain {{response}}
  8. Environmental damage {{response}}

data.stimulus:
QUESTION 2 - SCANNING TO FIND INFORMATION

Answer the questions with ONE WORD or NUMBER from the text.
data.template:
1. The normal speed of a modern HSR train is {{response}} kph.
  2. In {{response}} France received its first high-speed trains.
  3. There is more than {{response}} km of high-speed track in Spain.
  4. Many additional {{response}} are expected to come from HS2 in areas where not everyone is in employment.
  5. HS2 will allow London workers the opportunity to afford less expensive {{response}} in the North.
  6. The construction work will have an effect on the {{response}}.
  7. Some {{response}} think the true cost of HS2 will be $50 billion higher than the government’s expected budget.
  8. The {{response}} do not pay enough to cover the cost of running the highspeed trains in France.

options.label: will only benefit the North of England.
will take too long to complete.
is a misuse of public funds.

data.stimulus:
QUESTION 3 - IDENTIFYING ARGUMENT

For each question, choose ONE correct answer.

 

3.1. STOP HS2‘s main concern is that the high-speed rail link…

options.label: wants people to build houses in the North of England.
would like to make travel around the UK easier.
wants people to work in London.
would like to build cheap homes in the South.
the effects of the construction on the local people and land.
that costs will be higher than predicted.
that the cost will be £50 billion.
thinks HS2 is a good idea.
is not in favour of investment in HS2.
is unsure about the HS2 project.
is certain HS2 is a very bad project.

data.stimulus:
VOCABULARY SECTION


QUESTION 1 - VOCABULARY IN CONTEXT

Match the words in CAPITALS to their meanings. Select a word from the drop down. There are extra meanings you don't need.
data.template:
1. The government CLAIMS (line 12) {{response}}
  2. A complete WASTE of money (line 14) {{response}}
  3. Many people CANNOT AFFORD (line 21) {{response}}
  4. IN OTHER WORDS (line 27) {{response}}
  5. The CENTRAL argument (line 30) {{response}}
  6. It is ESTIMATED (line 39) {{response}}
  7. It is DEBATABLE (line 44) {{response}}

value: To say that something is true but you cannot prove it
What people think the value of something is (but are not sure)
Not clear because people may have different opinions

data.stimulus:
QUESTION 2 - WORD FORMATION

Read the text below. Use the word in CAPITALS to form a word that fits the gap. 
There is an example at the beginning.
data.template:
In the morning I usually (USUAL) take the underground. At that time of day it's crowded, you have to stand, and it's certainly not a {{response}} (RELAX ) way to travel. But the service is quick, frequent and {{response}} (RELY), which makes it by far the most {{response}} (PRACTICE) across the city in the rush hour.

Occasionally, though, I travel into town in a friend's car to go shopping and, quite honestly, I often find it an absolutely {{response}} (TERRIFY) experience. Every time we get onto the ring road, I'm {{response}} (ASTONISH) by the way people behave when they drive a car. Some are extremely {{response}} (AGGRESSION), driving straight at you to make you get out of their way, while others are {{response}} (COMPETE), trying to have races with other drivers all the time. They just seem {{response}} (CHILD) to me. Many of them look really {{response}} (PATIENT) and they’re always getting angry with other people, which seems to me a {{response}} (FOOL) way to start the day. What I find most {{response}} (PUZZLE) about this is the fact that by the time they actually get to their offices, they're probably too {{response}} (EXHAUST) to do a proper day's work.

response.value: Thousands of jobs will be created by HS2

data.stimulus:
GRAMMAR SECTION 

 

QUESTION 1 - PASSIVES

It is common to use passives in academic writing. Re-write the sentences below in the passive.

 

EXAMPLE:    The government is investing £50 billion in HSR.

£50 billion is being invested in HSR (by the government).

 

1.1. HS2 will create thousands of jobs.

metadata.sample_answer:
Thousands of jobs will be created (by HS2)

Thousands of jobs will be created by HS2

response.value: Historical buildings has been damaged by HS2

data.stimulus: 1.2. HS2 has caused damage to historical buildings.

metadata.sample_answer:
Damage has been caused to historical buildings (by HS2)

Damage has been caused to historical buildings by HS2

Damage to historical buildings has been caused (by HS2)

Damage to historical buildings has been caused by HS2

response.value: cheaper homes are founded in north by people

data.stimulus: 1.3. People find cheaper homes in the North.

metadata.sample_answer:
Cheaper homes are found in the North (by people)

Cheaper homes are found in the North by people

Cheaper homes are found in the North

response.value: Negative Effects is being caused by HS2

data.stimulus: 1.4. HS2 is already causing negative effects.

metadata.sample_answer:
Negative effects are already being caused (by HS2)

Negative effects are already being caused by HS2

Negative effects are already being caused

response.value: Investment in rail should have been supported by the goverrnment

data.stimulus: 1.5. The government should support investment in rail.

metadata.sample_answer:
Investment in rail should be supported (by the government)

Investment in rail should be supported by the government

Investment in rail should be supported

data.stimulus:
QUESTION 2 - REFERENCE WORDS

What do the highlighted words in the text refer to? Write the answer in the gaps below. There is an example.

 

EXAMPLE: Nowadays however, 300 kph is normal for highspeed trains and SOME can go even faster.

Some refers to: trains
